entities.title: President of Chile
entities.description: The president of Chile, officially known as the president of the Republic of Chile is the head of state and head of government of Chile. entities.description: Jan Jacob Slauerhoff, who published as J. Slauerhoff, was a Dutch poet and novelist. He is considered one of the most important Dutch language writers.

entities.title: Donald Bailey (civil engineer)
entities.description: Sir Donald Coleman Bailey, OBE was an English civil engineer who invented the Bailey bridge. Field Marshal Montgomery is recorded as saying that "without the Bailey bridge, we should not have won the war."

entities.title: Bailey bridge
entities.description: A Bailey bridge is a type of portable, pre-fabricated, truss bridge. It was developed in 1940–1941 by the British for military use during the Second World War and saw extensive use by British, Canadian and US military engineering units. A Bailey bridge has the advantages of requiring no special tools or heavy equipment to assemble. The wood and steel bridge elements were small and light enough to

heading: Births
txt: Roy Acuff, American singer-songwriter and fiddler (d. 1992)

Known as the "King of Country Music", Acuff is often credited with moving the genre from its early string band and "hoedown" format to the singer-based format that helped make it internationally successful. entities.title: Secretary of State for War and the Colonies
entities.description:
The Secretary of State for War and the Colonies was a British cabinet-level position responsible for the army and the British colonies. 
The Secretary was supported by an Under-Secretary of State for War and the Colonies.

txt: Alessandro Rolla, Italian violinist and composer (b. 1757)

entities.title: Alessandro Rolla
entities.description: Alessandro Rolla was an Italian viola and violin virtuoso, composer, conductor and teacher. His son, Antonio Rolla, was also a violin virtuoso and composer.

txt: Pierre Baillot, French violinist and composer (b. 1771)

entities.title: Pierre Baillot
entities.description: Pierre Marie François de Sales Baillot was a French violinist and composer born in Passy. He studied the violin under Giovanni Battista Viotti and taught at the Conservatoire de Paris together with Pierre Rode and Rodolphe Kreutzer, who wrote the Conservatoire's official violin method. He was sole author of the instructional L'Art du violon (1834). Baillot's teachings had a profound influence on t

entities.description: Johann Karl Simon Morgenstern was a German philologist in Livonia, the first director of the library of the Imperial University of Dorpat. He coined the term Bildungsroman.

entities.title: Isambard Kingdom Brunel
entities.description: Isambard Kingdom Brunel was an English civil engineer who is considered "one of the most ingenious and prolific figures in engineering history," "one of the 19th-century engineering giants," and "one of the greatest figures of the Industrial Revolution, [who] changed the face of the English landscape with his groundbreaking designs and ingenious constructions." Brunel built dockyards, the Great We

entities.title: Great Western Railway
entities.description: The Great Western Railway (GWR) was a British railway company that linked London with the southwest and west of England, the West Midlands, and most of Wales. It was founded in 1833, received its enabling Act of Parliament on 31 August 1835 and ran its first trains in 1838. It was engineered by Isambard Kingdom Brunel, who chose a broad gauge of 7 ft —later slightly widened to 7 ft 1⁄4 in —but, fr

heading: Deaths
txt: John Hanning Speke, English soldier and explorer (b. 1827)

entities.title: John Hanning Speke
entities.description: John Hanning Speke was an English explorer and officer in the British Indian Army who made three exploratory expeditions to Africa. He is most associated with the search for the source of the Nile and was the first European to reach Lake Victoria. Speke is also known for propounding the Hamitic hypothesis in 1863, in which he supposed that the Tutsi ethnic group were descendants of the biblical fi

heading: Deaths
txt: Charles-Amédée Kohler, Swiss chocolatier (b. 1790)

entities.title: Charles-Amédée Kohler
entities.description: Charles-Amédée Kohler was an early Swiss chocolate maker, chocolatier and entrepreneur who invented hazelnut chocolate, in his factory founded in 1830 in Lausanne. After his death the Kohler company continued in the Swiss chocolate industry, merged in 1911 with the Cailler and Peter chocolate brands and was later purchased by Nestlé in 1929.

heading: Deaths
txt: Joseph Plateau, Belgian physicist and academic (b. 1801)

entities.title: Joseph Plateau
entities.description: Joseph Antoine Ferdinand Plateau was a Belgian physicist and mathematician. He was one of the first people to demonstrate the illusion of a moving image. To do this, he used counterrotating disks with repeating drawn images in small increments of motion on one and regularly spaced slits in the other. He called this device of 1832 the phenakistiscope.

heading: Deaths
txt: Thomas Hawksley, English engineer (b. 1807)

entities.title: Thomas Hawksley
entities.description: Thomas Hawksley was an English civil engineer of the 19th century, particularly associated with early water supply and coal gas engineering projects. Hawksley was, with John Frederick Bateman, the leading British water engineer of the nineteenth century and was personally responsible for upwards of 150 water-supply schemes, in the British Isles and overseas.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ernest Gagnon, Canadian organist and composer (b. 1834)

entities.title: Ernest Gagnon
entities.description: Ernest Gagnon was a Canadian folklorist, composer, and organist. He is best known for compiling a large amount of French Canadian folk music which he published as Chansons populaires du Canada in 1865–1867. He was greatly admired for his virtuoso performances on the organ and was also considered an expert at plainsong accompaniment.

heading: Deaths
txt: Roman von Ungern-Sternberg, Austrian-Russian general (b. 1886)

entities.title: Roman von Ungern-Sternberg
entities.description: Baron Roman Fyodorovich von Ungern-Sternberg, often referred to as Baron Ungern, was an anticommunist general in the Russian Civil War and then an independent warlord who intervened in Mongolia against China. A part of the Russian Empire's Baltic German minority, Ungern was an ultraconservative monarchist who aspired to restore the Russian monarchy after the 1917 Russian Revolutions and to revive

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Literature
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Literature is a Swedish literature prize that is awarded annually, since 1901, to an author from any country who has, in the words of the will of Swedish industrialist Alfred Nobel, "in the field of literature, produced the most outstanding work in an idealistic direction". Though individual works are sometimes cited as being particularly noteworthy, the award is based on an aut

entities.title: Speaker of the United States House of Representatives
entities.description: The speaker of the United States House of Representatives, commonly known as the Speaker of the House, is the presiding officer of the United States House of Representatives. The office was established in 1789 by Article I, Section 2 of the U.S. Constitution. heading: Deaths
txt: André Tardieu, French journalist and politician, 97th Prime Minister of France (b. 1876)

entities.title: André Tardieu
entities.description: André Pierre Gabriel Amédée Tardieu was three times Prime Minister of France and a dominant figure of French political life in 1929–1932. He was a moderate conservative with a strong intellectual reputation, but became a weak prime minister at the start of the worldwide Great Depression.

entities.title: Prime Minister of France
entities.description: The prime minister of the French Republic, sometimes shortened to premier, is the head of government of France. During the Third and Fourth Republics, the head of government was formally called president of the Council of Ministers, generally shortened to president of the Council. entities.title: Hugo Raudsepp
entities.description: Hugo Raudsepp was an influential and prolific Estonian playwright and politician. In 1951 he was deported to the Irkutsk region by the Soviet authorities, where he died.

heading: Deaths

entities.title: Steve Brown (bass player)
entities.description: Theodore "Steve" Brown was a jazz musician best known for his work on string bass. Like many New Orleans bassists, he played both string bass and tuba professionally.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ulvi Cemal Erkin, Turkish composer and educator (b. 1906)

entities.title: Ulvi Cemal Erkin
entities.description: Ulvi Cemal Erkin was a member of the pioneer group of symphonic composers in Turkey, born in the period 1904–1910, who later came to be called The Turkish Five. These composers set out the direction of music in the newly established Turkish Republic. These composers distinguished themselves with their use of Turkish folk music and modal elements in an entirely western symphonic style.

heading: Deaths
txt: Franco Bordoni, Italian race car driver and pilot (b. 1913)

entities.description: Franco Bordoni-Bisleri was an Italian aviator and racing car driver. He is one of the top-scoring aces of the Regia Aeronautica, with 19 air victories. His nickname was "Robur" and was painted on most of his aircraft and racing cars.

The Bf 109 first saw operational service in 1937 during the Spanish Civil War and was still in service at the dawn of the jet age at the end of World War II in 1945. heading: Deaths
txt: Bill Evans, American pianist and composer (b. 1929)

entities.title: Bill Evans
entities.description: William John Evans was an American jazz pianist and composer who mostly played in trios. His use of impressionist harmony, inventive interpretation of traditional jazz repertoire, block chords, and trademark rhythmically independent, "singing" melodic lines continues to influence jazz pianists today.

entities.title: Prince Far I
entities.description: Prince Far I was a Jamaican reggae deejay, producer and a Rastafarian. He was known for his gruff voice and critical assessment of the Jamaican government. His track "Heavy Manners" used lyrics against measures initiated towards violent crime.

entities.description: Harry Lawton Calder was named as a Wisden Cricketer of the Year in 1918, then a 17 year old schoolboy. Calder is the youngest person to receive this accolade, one of the game's top honours, and the only Wisden Cricketer of the Year that never played first-class cricket.

entities.description: Louis Rasminsky, was the third Governor of the Bank of Canada from 1961 to 1973, succeeding James Coyne. He was succeeded by Gerald Bouey.

entities.title: Governor of the Bank of Canada
entities.description: The governor of the Bank of Canada is the chief executive officer of the Bank of Canada and acts as chair of its board of directors. The Bank of Canada Act, 1985, S. 6(1), provides that the governor and deputy governor shall be appointed by the directors with the approval of the Governor in Council.

He was a founding member of the band, and—along with vocalist Joey Ramone—remained a constant member throughout his entire career.

With 25 victories in the WRC, McRae held the record for the most wins in the series.

entities.title: Troy Kennedy Martin
entities.description: Troy Kennedy Martin was a Scottish-born film and television screenwriter. He created the long-running BBC TV police series Z-Cars (1962–1978), and the award-winning 1985 anti-nuclear drama Edge of Darkness. He also wrote the screenplay for the original version of The Italian Job (1969).

heading: Deaths
txt: Arrow, Caribbean singer-songwriter (b. 1949)

entities.title: Arrow (musician)
entities.description: Alphonsus Celestine Edmund Cassell MBE was a Montserratian calypso and soca musician, regarded as the first superstar of soca from Montserrat. He performed under the stage name Arrow. Internationally, his biggest hit song was "Hot Hot Hot" (1982), known from the original by Arrow and numerous later versions by other musicians.

heading: Deaths
txt: Frances Bay, Canadian-American actress (b. 1919)

entities.title: Frances Bay
entities.description: Frances Evelyn Bay was a Canadian-American character actress. In a career that spanned 35 years, she acted in a variety of roles both in film and television. Bay was inducted in Canada's Walk of Fame in 2008.

entities.title: Tibor Antalpéter

entities.title: Governor of Kansas
entities.description: The Governor of Kansas is the head of the executive branch of Kansas's state government and the commander-in-chief of the state's military forces. The governor has a duty to enforce state laws, and the power to either approve or veto bills passed by the Kansas Legislature, to convene the legislature at any time, and to grant pardons.
